newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: OPEC freezes output, vows quota compliance.
newsitem.headline: OPEC freezes output, vows quota compliance.

text.p: OPEC talks in Vienna resulted in an agreement to try to rescue weak oil prices by extending a freeze on the cartel's production quotas until the end of the year.
Saudi Arabia and Iran also extracted renewed vows from those of the 11 members - a majority - who flout the mandatory limits that they will now stop their cheating.

Prices ticked briskly up on the news from the Vienna conference of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries on Wednesday. North Sea Brent crude settled 35 cents firmer at $18.21 per barrel.
But sceptical analysts said that, longer term, the market would demand proof of actual production cuts.
"People will not believe that anything has changed until they see it," said Leo Drollas, economist at the London-based Centre for Global Energy Studies.
The accord that is being extended sets a ceiling on total OPEC volume at 25.03 million barrels daily, including exports by Iraq under its food-for-oil deal with the United Nations.
But violations by exporters like Venezuela and Nigeria have taken actual supply to 27 million.
Prices have sagged, down to around $18 per barrel from $25 in January, vexing Iran in particular, and apparently also irritating OPEC linchpin Saudi Arabia.
Ministers said there were no threats this time by the Saudis to turn up the taps on their huge unused capacity as a retaliatory measure.
But delegates believed that Oil Minister Erwin Arrieta of Venezuela got a tongue lashing at private talks with the Saudis' Ali Naimi and Iran's Gholamreza Aghazadeh.
Later, said a Gulf source, Venezuela confessed to excess of 800,000 barrels or 30 percent above its quota - something it has always stoutly denied.
"All of the cheaters made confessions," said this source.
The source said that all except three big Gulf producers -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates -- plus Libya and Indonesia were guilty to some degree.
Naimi meanwhile told lobby reporters that what followed was a "100 percent" commitment to quotas.
Some seasoned OPEC-watchers were sceptical.
John Lichtblau, head of Petroleum Industry Research Associates, deemed it "unthinkable" that populous, cash-pinched sellers like Venezuela and Nigeria could cut to quota.
U.S. oilman Oscar Wyatt questioned whether fuel demand would be strong enough to lift prices if OPEC produces as much as it is likely to do.
"There is nothing to lift this market...it would have to be some external event other than consumption," said Wyatt, retiring chairman of Coastal Corp.

OPEC's problem is that is lacks a mechanism to compel a sovereign state to honour its quotas, although Iraq was briefly an effective "policeman" in 1990 just before it invaded Kuwait and when its tanks stood on Gulf frontiers.
Its oil minister, Amir Rasheed, told reporters in Vienna on Wednesday, however, that promises to keep to quota would suffice now.
"We got their assurances and that is more efficient than any mechanism," he said.
